## Current recommended schedule (2024‑2025) | Age / Situation | Dose | Why that timing is chosen | |-----------------|------|----------------------------| | **Infants 12‑15 months** | **1st dose** of MMR (or MMR‑V if combined with varicella) | • By 12 months most maternal antibodies to measles, mumps and rubella have fallen to a level that no longer blocks the vaccine‑induced immune response.
• The immune system is mature enough to mount a strong, long‑lasting antibody response.
• Giving the dose before the peak age of measles exposure (≈12‑18 months) protects the child during the high‑risk toddler years.
• A single dose confers ~93 % protection against measles, ~78 % against mumps and ~97 % against rubella—enough to reduce disease incidence dramatically while still leaving a “window” for a booster. | | **Children 4‑6 years (usually at 4‑5 y)** | **2nd dose** of MMR (or MMR‑V) | • The second dose is **not a “booster”** for those who responded to the first dose; rather it is a “catch‑up” for the small fraction (~5–7 %) who did not develop protective immunity after the first injection (primary vaccine failure).
• By age 4‑5 the child’s immune system can generate an even higher antibody titre, giving >99 % seroconversion for all three viruses.
• This age coincides with school entry in most countries, a setting where respiratory viruses spread easily; ensuring near‑universal immunity before children mingle in classrooms helps maintain herd protection.
• The interval of 3–5 years also allows any mild adverse events (e.g., fever, rash) from the first dose to be well‑resolved before the second exposure. | | **Special circumstances** | • **Travel to measles‑endemic areas** – a dose as early as **6 months** may be given (off‑label in many countries) followed by the routine 12‑month dose and the second dose at 4‑6 y.
• **Outbreak control** – a second dose can be administered **as early as 4 weeks** after the first dose to rapidly increase immunity in a susceptible population.
